metadata.case_name: Owners of two residential buildings v. Bombay Building Repairs and Reconstruction Board

facts.text: Petitions by owners of two residential buildings in the city of Bombay, neither of which is, by reason of its having been recently constructed, either dilapidated or in dangerous condition.
Preamble of the Act recites collapses of residential buildings, acute shortage of housing accommodation, and problems of law and order arising from unceasing influx of persons into Bombay.
Act brought into force on October 1, 1969; cess payable from November 1, 1970; Act temporary, expires December 31, 1979.
Structural repairs defined as repairs or replacement of decayed, cracked, or out of plumb structural components... which if not carried out expeditiously, may result in collapse.
Board established under Ss. 3 and 4 to carry out structural and tenantable repairs, acquire and reconstruct beyond repair buildings, provide rehousing, demolish dangerous buildings.
Cess levied under S.27 on buildings and lands at prescribed rates; owner pays 10% of rateable value, recovers balance from tenant via rent increase.
Exemptions under S.28 for certain classes of buildings.
Buildings categorized under S.29 into three categories with different cess rates in Schedule.
Proceeds of cess credited to Consolidated Fund, then to Board's fund.
S.71 suspends S.23 of Bombay Rents Act 1947; Transfer of Property Act 1882 applies for tenantable repairs.
Prior to World War, buildings major investment, low construction and maintenance costs, tenants' market.
Post-World War, rent freezing under Rent Control Act, scarce materials, rising costs led to neglect of repairs.
City Corporation survey 1956: 36,000 residential buildings, 17,490 built prior to 1905; categories by construction type.
Survey life expectancy: 5,081 buildings 5 years future life, 3,549 6-10 years, etc.; total families in imminent need: 1,04,270.
Development Plan Report 1964: 23% tenements needing extensive repairs, 1,000 immediate demolition.
House collapses average 125 per year.
Bedekar Committee 1965: causes of collapses - rent freeze, material costs, leakages, overcrowding, land values; 18,000 repair notices since 1960, only 1/3 complied.
Bedekar: 386 unsafe buildings, more by 1970-1980; recommendations for repairs, acquisition, transit camps.
Government proposals published June 3, 1968 for public opinion.
Petitioners' buildings in sound condition, not requiring structural repairs during Act's life.

legal_issues.text: Whether imposition of cess on residential buildings in sound condition amounts to unreasonable restriction violating Art. 19(1)(f).
Whether Act violates Art. 14 by failing to recognise material differences between buildings' physical conditions and treating unequals as equals.
Whether exemptions in S.28 are arbitrary and violate Art. 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cess on sound buildings is unreasonable restriction under Art. 19(1)(f) as it provides bounties to neglectful owners at expense of diligent ones.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 19(1)(f); Cooley on Taxation; Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments v. Lakshmindra

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art. 14 by equating dangerous/dilapidated buildings with sound ones; classification into categories not rational as based on age not condition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 14; K.T. Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala

petitioner_arguments.text: Exemptions under S.28 cls. (g),(h),(i),(j) arbitrary without principle.

respondent_arguments.text: Imposition under Art. 246(3) read with Entry 49 List II; for public purpose, not unreasonable restriction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 246(3), Seventh Schedule List II Entry 49

respondent_arguments.text: Intelligible classification of buildings with rational nexus to objects; not discriminatory.
Exemptions in S.28 consonant with objects and scope of Act.

court_reasoning.text: Cess for public purpose: to prevent collapses, preserve buildings, provide agency for repairs where owners reluctant; proceeds augment Consolidated Fund.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax valid if within competence, public purpose, not violating Part III; incidental benefit to some does not invalidate.

court_reasoning.text: Classification based on intelligible differentia (residential tenanted vs others; existing vs new; three categories by age/construction type) with rational nexus to preventing collapses in Bombay context.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Surveys and Bedekar Committee justify categories; tax on rateable value, shared owner-tenant; not quid pro quo but public purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Exemptions valid: each class distinct (e.g., co-op societies different from landlord-tenant; licensees no rent freeze issues).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classes form distinct groups with different considerations.

holdings.text: Act valid; does not violate Arts. 14 or 19(1)(f); classifications reasonable.
Classification into categories A,B,C based on age and construction type has rational nexus.

outcome.summary: Petitions challenging validity of Bombay Building Repairs and Reconstruction Board Act, 1969 dismissed; Act held valid, not violative of Arts. 14 or 19(1)(f).

key_quotes.text: The purpose is to prevent collapses and the suffering they must cause including rendering several persons homeless.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines public purpose of the cess

key_quotes.text: A taxing statute is not invalid on the ground of discrimination merely because other objects could have been, but are not taxed by the legislature.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The classification must be based on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or objects grouped together from others left out of the group, and that differentia must have a rational nexus with the object of the statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
